summary: Stomach cancer, also known as gastric cancer, is a malignant tumor of the stomach that develops in the lining of the stomach due to abnormal cell growth. It is often diagnosed late due to non-specific early symptoms, leading to a generally poor prognosis. The cancer can spread to other parts of the body, including the liver, lungs, bones, lining of the abdomen, and lymph nodes. Globally, it is a significant cause of cancer-related deaths.
causes: Genetic syndromes (e.g., hereditary diffuse gastric cancer)
risk_factors: Dietary factors (fried foods, processed meat, red meat, brackens)
symptoms: Bloating of the stomach after meals
diagnosis: Blood tests (complete blood count, fecal occult blood test)
Imaging tests (CT scan, PET scan, abdominal ultrasound)
treatments: Surgery (gastrectomy, endoscopic mucosal resection, endoscopic submucosal dissection)
Chemotherapy (e.g., 5-fluorouracil, cisplatin, epirubicin, etoposide, docetaxel, oxaliplatin, capecitabine, irinotecan)
Targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for HER2-overexpressing tumors)
Treatment of H. pylori infection (for MALT lymphomas)
subtypes: Lymphomas (e.g., extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphomas, diffuse large B-cell lymphomas)
